animalOfTheDay.name: warthog
facts: Warthogs kneel on calloused wrists to graze low vegetation.
Warthogs have facial 'warts' that protect eyes during fights.
Birds like mongooses remove ticks from warthogs during grooming sessions.
They reverse into burrows – tusks facing outward to deter predators.

calendar.name: vampire bat
facts: Bat saliva contains draculin – an anticoagulant studied for stroke treatment.
Vampire bats share regurgitated blood with starving colony members – reciprocal altruism.
Vampires run on ground using folded wings as front legs.
They use infrared sensors on noses to detect blood vessels.

calendar.name: vicuna
facts: Vicuñas produce the finest wool – fibers measure 12 micrometers (human hair: 75).
They have lower incisor teeth that grow continuously like rodents.
Vicuñas spit foul-smelling cud at competitors during disputes.
Inca royalty wore vicuña robes; illegal poaching still threatens populations.

calendar.name: viper
facts: Horned vipers in deserts move via sidewinding to avoid hot sand.
Gaboon vipers have longest fangs (2 inches) and highest venom yield.
Their hinged fangs fold against the roof of mouth when not striking.
Vipers have heat-sensing pits detecting temperature changes as small as 0.003°C.

calendar.name: vulture
facts: They have an excellent sense of smell.
Vultures are scavenging birds of prey.
They are known for their bald heads, which help keep them clean while feeding.
Vultures play a crucial role in ecosystems by cleaning up carcasses.

calendar.name: wallaby
facts: Wallabies hop efficiently – energy use doesn't increase with speed.
Rock wallabies scale cliffs using textured soles and tail balancing.
They practice embryonic diapause; pausing development until environmental conditions improve.
Wallabies cool by licking forearms; saliva evaporation lowers blood temperature.

calendar.name: walrus
facts: They are social animals and live in large herds.
They are found in Arctic waters.
Walruses are large marine mammals known for their prominent tusks.
Walruses use their tusks to haul themselves onto ice and to forage for food.

calendar.name: warthog
facts: Warthogs have facial 'warts' that protect eyes during fights.
Warthogs kneel on calloused wrists to graze low vegetation.
They reverse into burrows – tusks facing outward to deter predators.
Birds like mongooses remove ticks from warthogs during grooming sessions.

randomAnimals.name: meerkat
facts: They teach their young how to handle dangerous prey, like scorpions, by disabling them first.
Meerkats are immune to many venoms, including scorpion stings.
They take turns standing guard on their hind legs to watch for predators.
Meerkats are highly social, living in groups called mobs or clans.

randomAnimals.name: jaguar
facts: Jaguars are excellent swimmers and often hunt fish, turtles, and caimans.
They have the strongest bite force of any big cat, capable of crushing skulls.
Jaguars are the largest big cats in the Americas and the third-largest in the world.
Their spots, called rosettes, are unique to each individual, like fingerprints.

randomAnimals.name: hamster
facts: Hamsters have cheek pouches that can stretch to store food, sometimes as large as their bodies.
They are nocturnal animals, meaning they are most active during the night.
Hamsters can run up to 5 miles in a single night on their exercise wheels.
In the wild, hamsters live in burrows that can be up to 3 feet deep.
